Laboratoire de Chimie Catalyse Polymères Procédés CNRS UMR 5265 Université Claude Bernard Lyon1 CPE Lyon 43 Bd du 11 novembre 1918 Villeurbanne 69616 cedex France Graphical abstract The hybrid catalyst Cu(II)phen@SBA-15showedahighactivityforthemulticomponent [3+2]-cycloaddition of azides with alkynes in pure water. A copper(II)-phenanthroline hybrid material based on the SBA-15 architecture was prepared using a two-step synthesis through co-condensation of 5-[N,N-bis-3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl]ureyl-1,10-phenanthroline with tetraethoxysilane, followed by coordination of Cu(OAc)2. The obtained hybrid material, Cu(II)phen@SBA-15, was fully characterized, at each stage of the preparation, by means of bulk and molecular techniques to assess both textural and structural catalyst features using XRD, XPS, EPR, HRTEM, SEM, solid-state NMR UV–vis and IR analytical tools. The characterization results altogether confirmed the structural integrity of the mesoporous host and the successful anchoring of the copper-phenanthroline complex as discrete mononuclear Cu(II)L species. The catalytic performances of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 were evaluated in the aqueous 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of azides with alkynes using a multicomponent one-pot synthesis where organic azides were produced in situ from organic bromide (or aryl diazonium salts or epoxides), providing for safer synthetic technologies. The catalyst proved to be highly active under mild reaction conditions (0.5mol%, 70°C) over a broad range of substrates, providing 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles in high yields. Keywords Copper SBA-15 Heterogeneous catalyst [3+2]-Cycloaddition Click reaction 1 Introduction The construction of structurally complex molecules by means of powerful, selective and environmentally friendly transformations is an on-going field of research which continues to drive a lot of attention in the scientific community. In this regard, the copper(I)-catalyzed azide–alkyne 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition yielding triazoles is now widely recognized as a highly efficient and reliable ligation process to create robust linkages in a regio-controlled manner between synthon units [1–3]. While the thermal-promoted cycloaddition, initially discovered by Huisgen [4,5], has not been extensively used in synthesis due to poor regioselectivies, the copper- and ruthenium-catalyzed versions, independently disclosed by Meldal [6] and Sharpless [7], were rapidly established as a leading regioselective transformation, with numerous important applications in chemical-biology [8–10] and material science [11]. Environmental concerns as well as toxicity issues from copper species in compounds of biological interest have led to the development of immobilized catalytic systems, allowing for an efficient copper removal by simple filtration. Copper catalysts have been immobilized as molecular complexes and nanoparticles on a variety of supports including silica, zeolites, iron oxides, and carbon-based materials [12–17]. Another concern with this transformation, especially on a multi-gram scale, is the handling of hazardous organic azides which are often thermally- and shock-sensitive. Fokin and Van der Eycken addressed this issue with the in situ formation of organic azides, through a multi-component procedure involving sequential azide formation/1,3-dipolar cycloaddition in the same reaction vessel [18,19]. In continuation of our interest for methodologies involving safe and environmentally friendly conditions [20,21], we have recently reported on the preparation of graphite-supported ultra-small copper nanoparticles and their use as efficient catalyst in the multi-component synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles starting with alkynes and organic bromides, aryl diazonium salts or epoxides as co-reagents [22]. Although the graphite supported Cu NPs catalyst could be readily recovered by filtration leaving the crude mixture virtually free of copper residues, one limitation of this methodology towards enhanced catalyst efficiency was the low dispersion of hydrophobic graphite into the aqueous reaction medium. As a follow-up of this work, we report herein on the synthesis and characterization of a mononuclear copper(II) phenanthroline complex immobilized onto SBA-15 silica and its application in the multicomponent synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles using water as green solvent. Our approach towards catalyst design relies on two key factors: i) the use of high surface area hydrophilic silica-based support to allow for better compatibility between the solid catalyst, the reactants and the aqueous phase and ii) the appealing structural and chemical properties of the phenanthroline (phen) scaffold [23] (i.e. rigidity, planarity, strong chelating capability) to minimize metal lixiviation during aqueous catalysis. To the best of our knowledge, such an approach has never been reported for the multicomponent synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of phen@SBA-15. Phen-functionalized mesoporous SBA-15 silica was synthesized by adaptation of literature procedures [24,25]. Typically, Pluronic P123 (4.1g) was dissolved in distilled water (30mL) and 2M HCl solution (120mL) at 35°C. When the solution was homogeneous, a mixture of TEOS (8.3g) and phen-Si (0.4g) was added drop wise under vigorous stirring. The sol-gel had the following molar composition: 1 TEOS: 0.0177 P123: 0.015 phen-Si: 5.09 HCl: 202 H2O. The mixture was stirred at 35°C for 24h and then transferred to an autoclave and aged for 48h at 100°C. The solid product was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried overnight at room temperature. The surfactant P123 was removed by Soxhlet extraction with ethanol for 48h to obtain a white solid (2.3g). Synthesis of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15. Phen@SBA-15 (1g, 0.2mmol/g dry silica) was suspended in 20mL of methanol. Copper(II) acetate (0.074g, 2 eq with respect to grafted phen) was added and the mixture was refluxed for 24h. The solid was then filtered, washed with methanol and dried at 60°C. The solid was further washed by soxhlet extraction with methanol for 5h to remove excess of copper. A light blue solid was obtained (0.96g). 2.2 General procedure for the [3+2]-cycloaddition A 15mL sealed tube was charged with benzyl bromide (1.0mmol), sodium azide (1.0mmol), phenylacetylene (1.5mmol), Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 (0.5–1mol%) and 2.5mL of H2O. The mixture was degassed for 2min with N2, then the tube was sealed and the reaction mixture was heated at 70°C for the desired reaction time. After this time, the mixture was diluted with EtOAc (10mL) and H2O (5mL) and the aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc (3×10mL). The collected organic extracts were dried over Na2SO4, filtered and evaporated to dryness. The crude was purified either by flash chromatography on silica gel or by precipitation to give the pure triazole product. 1-Benzyl-4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazole 1a. HRMS (ESI) calcd for C16H16ON3 [M+H+]: 266.1287, found: 266.1283. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of Cu(II)-phenanthroline based materials Among the different immobilization strategies, we chose to pursue a covalent approach known to help reducing metal leaching and subsequent product contamination issues. In this regard, mesoporous SBA-15 type silica is a particularly well-suited host for the immobilization of catalytically relevant species due to its high surface area (up to 1000m2/g), large pore diameter (∼6–8nm) with narrow pore size distribution and ease of functionalization [31–33]. In addition, the rigidity of the silica matrix might provide for better stability of the bound functional groups during aqueous catalysis. Our synthetic strategy leading to Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 involves a two-step procedure as shown in Scheme 1 . Thus, to ensure a good dispersion of the organic functions within the silica matrix, tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) and a phen ligand bearing two siloxane moieties, 5-[N,N-bis-3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl]ureyl-1,10-phenantroline (phen-Si, Scheme S1 in Supporting information), were first co-condensed in the presence of Pluronic P123 structure directing agent (SDA) yielding hybrid phen@SBA-15 after SDA and unreacted phen precursor removal. Metalation of the phen@SBA-15 hybrid occurred in a second step using Cu(OAc)2 as Cu(II) precursor in refluxing methanol. The phenanthroline-based hybrid materials were fully characterized at each step of the synthesis by means of molecular and physical techniques including FTIR and diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopies, X-ray diffraction, N2 sorption, XPS, elemental analyses, solid-state NMR (for phen@SBA-15) and EPR (for Cu(II)phen@SBA-15). The successful incorporation and integrity of the phen group in phen@SBA-15 was assessed by 13C NMR and FTIR. As shown in Fig. S1 (Supporting information), the 13C CP MAS NMR spectrum of phen@SBA-15 corresponds to the solution-phase spectrum of the phen-Si precursor confirming that the phen fragment remained intact throughout the one-pot functionalization and template removal processes. In particular, one can clearly distinguish the peaks at 7.5, 20.8 and 41.2ppm associated with the propyl chain and those at 155 and 127–150ppm originating respectively from the CO amide functions and the aromatic carbons. The inclusion of the phen ligand in phen@SBA-15 was also demonstrated by FTIR (Fig. S2, Supporting information) with the presence of bands at 1705, 1634, 1553 and 1521cm−1 typical of the absorption vibrations of the urea groups (NHCONH) in agreement with previous reports [24,25,34,35]. The negligible absorption peaks of the P123 template (2900–2700cm−1) suggest that most of the surfactant has been removed from the pores. The tertiary silicon peaks (Tm =RSi-(OSi)m-(OH)3-m) at around −65.7ppm in the 29Si MAS NMR spectrum of phen@SBA-15 (Fig. S3, Supporting information) are indicative of the presence of covalently bonded organic groups through siloxane Si-O-Si linkages. Note that the absence of T0 sites at 41ppm confirms that each of the ethoxysilane groups in phen-Si have been involved, at least, in one covalent bond with the silica framework. Quantitative determination of the organic content in phen@SBA-15 (Table S1, Supporting information) was obtained from nitrogen elemental analysis as TGA and carbon elemental analysis proved to be unreliable due to the presence of residual ethoxy groups as evidenced in the 13C CP MAS NMR spectrum of phen@SBA-15 (Fig. S1). Thus, the phen group loading corrected from sample humidity, that is, by considering the SiO2 content of the TGA run at 1000°C, found to be 0.20mmol/g dry silica, which corresponds to a site density of 0.17 phen/nm2. The site density was deliberately kept low to ensure site isolation and hence prevent the formation of a mixture of mono- and bis(phenanthroline) Cu(II) complexes. The physicochemical and textural properties of phen@SBA-15 before and after incorporation of copper(II) acetate are summarized in Table 1 and small angle powder XRD patterns are presented in Fig. 1 . Three well resolved Bragg peaks in the 2θ-range of 0.5–3° that correspond to (100), (110) and (200) reflections were observed for both materials and are indicative of hexagonally ordered mesophases typical of the SBA-15 architecture. Upon metalation, however, one can note a marked decrease in intensity of the d100 reflection as well as a clear shift to higher 2θ values (from 104 to 101Å for d100, Table 1). The reduction in diffraction intensity could be attributed to local disorder and/or due to contrast matching between the amorphous silicate framework and the metal complex located inside the pore channels while the 2θ variation could result from a contraction of the pore volume after Cu(OAc)2 introduction. The ordering of the Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 material was further confirmed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) (Fig. 2 , left) which showed the presence of regular arrays of uniform channels indicating that the highly ordered hexagonal structure of SBA-15 can substantially be conserved after the two-step preparation process. Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 (Fig. 2, right and middle) revealed the presence of separate hexagonal prisms with a relatively uniform size of 1μm. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of phen@SBA-15 before and after copper(II) introduction are of type IV according to the IUPAC classification and typical of mesoporous solids (Fig. S4, top, Supporting information) [36]. The isotherms displayed sharp steps with hysteresis loops at relative pressure P/P0 of 0.6-0.8 corresponding to the filling of regular mesopores in good agreement with the narrow pore size distributions shown in Fig. S4 (bottom). The decrease in surface area (from 692 to 570m2.g−1), pore volume (0.99 to 0.94cm3.g−1) and pore diameter (64 to 62Å) observed for Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 with respect to parent phen@SBA-15 confirms the incorporation of Cu(II) in the channels of SBA-15 (Table 1). Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 was found to contain 1.15%wt Cu and 1.04%wt N suggesting that each Cu(II) ion is, on average, surrounded by one phenanthroline ligand (Cu/phen=1.16, Table S1) in total accord with the low phenanthroline density present in phen@SBA-15 (0.17phen/nm2). Electron paramagnetic spectroscopy (EPR) proved to be a very useful and informative method to gain insight into the geometry around the metal ion but also to provide evidence of the coordination of Cu(II) ions to supported phen ligand upon metalation by Cu(OAc)2 of parent phen@SBA-15. The EPR spectrum of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 recorded at 130K (Fig. 3 , top) exhibits a single signal between 2500 and 3600G corresponding to typical mononuclear Cu(II) center with characteristic four-line hyperfine patterns (I=3/2 for both 63Cu and 65Cu) [37]. No evidence of the presence of dimeric Cu2(OAc)4 and/or supported dinuclear Cu(II) species was noticed in the field regions of H<2500 and H>3600G (Fig. S5, Supporting information). Comparing the EPR spectrum of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 with that of its molecular analogue Cu(II)phen-Si, obtained by metalation of parent phen-Si precursor (Fig. S6, Supporting information) showed that the high symmetry of the isotropic signal (giso =2.145) in Cu(II)phen-Si (arising from both ideal octahedral geometry and low dipolar interactions) was totally lost in the case of the immobilized Cu(II) species with the concomitant appearance of a hyperfine structure. This suggests that the copper(II) centers in Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 are quite isolated which is in agreement with the low phen loading (0.17phen/nm2) obtained from elemental analyses and that the Cu(II) coordination environment in the confined space of the pores is somewhat distorted with respect to its molecular analogue. Note that a change in the chelation of the Cu(II) center upon immobilization, i.e. through the formation of a six-membered metal chelate with the bis-urea −NHCONR-CONH- group present in the phenanthroline scaffold, has been ruled out based on literature precedents [24,25], the strong and entropically favored binding properties of the phenanthroline compared to other chelating systems [23] and the observation of similar EPR spectra evolutions for complexes holding and lacking urea moieties, as depicted in Figs. S6 and S7 respectively. g and a tensors of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 deduced from simulated EPR signal (Fig. S8, Supporting information) were found to be respectively [2.045 2.063 2.3] (g|| =2.3,g⊥ =2.054,) and [10.7 10.7 175] G (a|| =175G, a⊥=10.7G). The g values and hyperfine coupling constants are consistent with a unique mononuclear Cu(II) surface species where the cupric ions are in distorted octahedral or square pyramidal symmetry [38]. The R value ((g2–g1)/(g3–g2)) of 0.08 also confirmed the square pyramidal coordination of the ligands around the Cu(II) center [39]. Interestingly, the second derivative spectrum of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 in the gx,y region (Fig. 3, bottom) evidenced superhyperfine splittings due to nuclear coupling from the nitrogen of the phen ligand. The presence of 5 well-resolved lines with a coupling constant a of 14.3G (14N I=1) is a clear indication that the coordination sphere around the Cu(II) ions is composed of only one phen ligand (2N). The coordination environment of the Cu(II) center in Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 was further assessed by means of DR UV–vis and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopies. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the DR UV–vis spectrum of phen@SBA-15 is characterized by two intense absorption bands at 228 and 265nm typical of the phenanthroline ligand (π-π* and n-π* transitions) [23]. Upon introduction of Cu(OAc)2, a red shift of the major electronic transition from 265 to 272nm was observed which is consistent with coordination to Cu(II) ions (Fig. 4b) [24,25,34,35]. Note that the characteristic absorption bands associated with d–d transitions expected in the lower-energy region (500–800nm) for Cu(II) complexes were absent in the DR UV–vis spectrum of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 probably arising from the very low concentration of copper in the catalyst (0.22mmol/g). Chelation of the surface phenanthroline ligands to Cu(II) centers was further assessed by N1s XPS characterization. The N–1s XPS spectrum of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 exhibited a single peak centered at 399.5eV (Fig. S9) in line with other literature data related to 1,10-phenanthroline metal chelates [40,41]. The ΔE chemical shift of 0.9eV when compared to free phen ligand (N–1s electron binding energy=398.9eV) is a clear indication of the coordination of nitrogen atom to Cu(II) centers. For the sake of completeness, the binding energies of the N–1s peaks of the phen-Si precursor and its metalated counterpart, Cu(II)phen-Si were compared. From the high resolution N–1s spectrum, we found photoemissions at 398.8 and 399.5eV for phen-Si and Cu(II)phen-Si respectively, confirming that the energy binding shift of 0.7eV resulted from the chelation of copper to nitrogen atoms. In addition, the presence of carbonyl functions arising from acetate groups and urea moieties was evidenced by the peak at 288.5eV in the C–1s XPS spectrum of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 (Fig. S10). Note that attempts to determine the Cu ion oxidation state from the Cu2p XPS spectrum failed as increased reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) was observed by prolonging the acquisition time [42]. 3.2 Catalytic results The catalytic activity of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 was then evaluated for the Huisgen 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of organic azides with alkynes, leading to the corresponding triazoles. We conducted preliminary studies on a model multicomponent process involving the reaction of an equimolar mixture of benzyl bromide, sodium azide and phenylacetylene in water at 70°C for 4h, in the presence of 1 mol% of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 (Table 2 , entry 1). The promising isolated yield in the 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles product 1a obtained on an average of two runs (66%) prompted us to investigate further the catalytic activity of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 in this multicomponent transformation. Bisacetylene, likely resulting from the Glaser-type dimerization of acetylene, was identified as one of the major side product. To limit this unwanted dimerization process and improve the reaction yields, the reaction mixture was carefully degased through nitrogen bubbling for 5min before the heating was turned on and a slight excess of phenylacetylene (1.5 eq. with respect to benzyl bromide) was used. Under these conditions, a greatly improved yield (89%) was obtained after purification of the product 1a by chromatography (entry 2). Decreasing the reaction time from 4 to 1 or 2h resulted in significantly diminished yields (entries 3–4) while increasing the reaction time from 4 to 6 and 12h led to further improvement of the reaction yield, achieving nearly full conversion (97–98%, entries 3–4). Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 was shown to perform even better (98 vs 94%, entry 7) than its soluble counterpart Cu(phen)(OAc)2 [43]. The influence of the temperature on catalyst activity was also investigated. The cycloaddition was found to be very sluggish at room temperature with a yield of 12% in the triazole product after 6h (entry 8), while in refluxing water some catalyst degradation occurred attaining a yield of 81% (entry 9) against 89% at 70°C (entry 2) under the same 4h period of time. Decreasing the catalyst loading from 1 mol% to 0.5 mol% Cu did not altered the reaction yield (entry 10), whereas a further decrease to 0.1 mol% Cu strongly hampered the multicomponent process with a drop in the reaction yield from 98 to 10% (compare entries 5 and 10 with entry 11). A background reaction secured that the catalytic activity observed was exclusively promoted by the Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 catalyst since in its absence the triazole formation was not observed even at longer reaction time (entry 12). As expected, the high hydrophilicity of the SBA-15 silica support favors the good dispersion of the catalyst in water and is a key parameter for the excellent catalytic activity observed with the Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 catalyst. By contrast, the use of a CuO/graphite catalyst [22] under the same conditions led to the corresponding triazole 1a in modest yield (40%) likely due, as mentioned in the introductive part, to the very low dispersion of the hydrophobic graphite support in the reaction medium (entry 13). Note that the use of an external reducing agent such as sodium ascorbate was not required since sodium azide played this role, as previously reported [44]. Having carefully optimized the experimental conditions for the multicomponent process on a model reaction, we explored further the scope of this methodology on representative examples. All the reactions were carried out in water with a catalyst loading of 0.5mol%, at 70°C during a reaction time varying from 6 to 14h. The results depicted in Table 3 revealed that sodium azide is able to react with a variety of organic bromides including benzylic, allylic as well as α-keto bromides, to form the corresponding organic azides which then smoothly reacted with phenylacetylene to give the corresponding triazoles 1a-c in good to excellent yield (74–98%). Notably, the mild conditions required for this process allowed for the use of ester bromide derivatives yielding 91% of 1d without trace of hydrolysis product. For all examples reported in Table 2, the triazoles were obtained as only one regioisomer (1,4-substituted product) even for the bis-triazole 1e issued from the reaction with 1,4-bis(ethynyl)benzene. Interestingly, this methodology was not restricted to the use of organic bromides as electrophiles since NaN3 also reacted smoothly with aryl diazonium salt and epoxide starting reagents, affording after subsequent reaction with phenylacetylene the triazoles 1f and 1 g in good yields (61 and 85% respectively). Note that the opening of epoxide by NaN3 selectively occurred at the benzylic position since the signal of the resulting primary alcohol was identified as a triplet by 1H NMR in DMSO-d6, in good agreement with the attribution provided by Yus et al. [30] The heterogeneous nature of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 greatly facilitated the purification process through a single filtration since the only by-product formed was NaBr, leaving the cycloadducts 1a–g free of copper residue (<10ppb) as determined by ICP-MS analysis. The methodology proved to be robust upon scale up, since triazoles 1a and 1d were isolated on a multi-gram scale with similar yields. From a practical point of view, compounds 1e–g could be conveniently purified by precipitation in a mixture of EtOAc and petroleum ether, avoiding the use of column chromatography. 3.3 Recycling studies and characterization of the spent Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 catalyst Recycling experiments were carried out using the benchmark multicomponent reaction involving benzyl bromide/sodium azide/phenylacetylene in a 1:1:1.5 molar ratio under optimized conditions (0.5mol% catalyst, 70°C, 6h). Typically, at completion of the first run (6h) using the fresh catalyst, the solid was separated by filtration from the reaction mixture, washed with CH2Cl2 and dried under vacuum at room temperature before being engaged in a new catalytic cycle. The results showed that while exhibiting high activity in the first run, catalyst deactivation started to occur in the 2nd and 3rd cycles going from nearly quantitative yield to respectively 55 and 26% yield. Despite these disappointing yields, we mention that the selectivity was not affected since the 1,4-triazole 1a was the only recovered product along with remaining starting materials. To get deeper insights into the origin of the observed deactivation, Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 was submitted to thorough characterization after the recycling study. Examination of the Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 spent catalyst by XRD showed high degree of hexagonal mesoscopic organization of the solid with no evidence of clustering as demonstrated in the low- and wide-angle XRD patterns displayed respectively in Figs. S11 and S12 (Supporting information). This suggests that no wholesale collapse of the mesostructure has occurred and that Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 exhibited high hydrothermal stability over the 18h of reuse. The integrity of the supported Cu(II)phen species was fully retained after reaction as assessed by FT-IR and DR UV–vis spectroscopies. One can clearly observe in the IR spectral region comprised between 1700 and 1500cm−1 the main bands associated with the CONH- amide groups of the phenanthroline ligand (Fig. S13) with a slight increase in intensity of the band at 1635cm−1 which may originate from the presence of physisorbed water. No major changes were also observed in the DR UV–vis spectrum of the used Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 catalyst (Fig. S14), in particular no blue shift of the absorption band at 272nm was evidenced which is a clear indication that phenanthroline remained coordinated to the copper centers. The active sites integrity was further corroborated by EPR characterization. As shown in Fig. 5 (top), no evolution of the EPR spectral pattern and/or intensity was observed after aqueous catalysis suggesting similar local environments and geometry of the supported Cu(II)phen complex in fresh and spent Cu(II)phen@SBA-15. More importantly, the coordination state of copper to phenanthroline was further and unambiguously assessed by the persistence of the superhyperfine splittings due to nuclear coupling from the nitrogen phen ligand (Fig. 5, bottom). Therefore, it seems that the catalyst deactivation observed upon successive recycling cannot be interpreted in terms of loss of structural ordering of the mesoporous silica support or in terms of substantial modifications of the local environment around the copper metal center. Examination of the textural properties of the used catalyst by nitrogen sorption measurements, however, allowed shedding some light on this deactivation phenomenon since a marked decrease in both mesoporosity (from 0.94 to 0.75cm3 g−1) and specific surface area (from 570 to 420m2 g−1) was demonstrated. The diminution of the textural properties after reuse could stem from the presence of adsorbed species (i.e. reactant, product or salt) nearby the active sites thus hampering full accessibility to and from the metal centre located inside the pores. This was confirmed by XPS surface analysis of elements which showed a significant increase in both nitrogen and carbon surface contents of around 40% (Table S2, Supporting information) whereas the Cu concentration remained nearly the same. The concentration of residual copper species remaining in the solvent after a single filtration was measured by ICP-MS and revealed that more than 99.5% of the copper initially introduced remained anchored to the phen@SBA-15 structure. These results indicate that even though the catalyst cannot be recycled it might be efficiently reprocessed since a simple filtration left the product virtually free of copper species. 4 Conclusion In this report, a Cu(II) complex bearing a chelating phenanthroline ligand has been prepared by immobilization onto SBA-15 type silica. The covalent link to the silica matrix has been first introduced through the phenanthroline ligand followed by subsequent metalation of the resulting organically modified silica. Characterization data of the final Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 hybrid material revealed the presence of quite isolated mononuclear Cu(II) complex at the surface of the solid, each Cu(II) center being surrounded by one phenanthroline ligand. The catalytic performance of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 was then evaluated in the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of organic azides with phenylacetylene. To provide safer and more sustainable synthetic technologies, a three-component click procedure was implemented to avoid isolation of hazardous organic azides and water was used as the sole reaction medium. The Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 catalyst proved to be highly active and selective under mild reaction conditions (0.5mol%, 70°C) over a broad range of substrates achieving up to 98% isolated yield in the 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles product after a 6h period time. Attempts to recycle the Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 catalyst revealed a continuous decrease in activity from 98 to 55% to 26% for respectively the second and third run. The observed deactivation was more likely attributed to a loss of some of the textural properties of the support with a significant decrease in both surface area and pore volume rather than to a progressive dissolution of the copper in the reaction medium or a change in the catalyst structural features as demonstrated respectively by ICP-MS analysis and UV–vis and EPR spectroscopies. coredata.dc:description: A copper(II)-phenanthroline hybrid material based on the SBA-15 architecture was prepared using a two-step synthesis through co-condensation of 5-[N,N-bis-3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl]ureyl-1,10-phenanthroline with tetraethoxysilane, followed by coordination of Cu(OAc)2. The obtained hybrid material, Cu(II)phen@SBA-15, was fully characterized, at each stage of the preparation, by means of bulk and molecular techniques to assess both textural and structural catalyst features using XRD, XPS, EPR, HRTEM, SEM, solid-state NMR UV–vis and IR analytical tools. The characterization results altogether confirmed the structural integrity of the mesoporous host and the successful anchoring of the copper-phenanthroline complex as discrete mononuclear Cu(II)L species. The catalytic performances of Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 were evaluated in the aqueous 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of azides with alkynes using a multicomponent one-pot synthesis where organic azides were produced in situ from organic bromide (or aryl diazonium salts or epoxides), providing for safer synthetic technologies. The catalyst proved to be highly active under mild reaction conditions (0.5mol%, 70°C) over a broad range of substrates, providing 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles in high yields.
coredata.dc:title: Copper(II)-phenanthroline hybrid material as efficient catalyst for the multicomponent synthesis of 1,2,3-triazoles via sequential azide formation/1,3-dipolar cycloaddition
